PARAM_DESCRIPTION.SP: : real number used to determine the effective rank of , which is defined as the order of the largest leading triangular submatrix R1 in the QR factorization with pivoting of, whose estimated condition number < 1/RCON.

PARAM_DESCRIPTION.P: : integer vector on entry, if JPVT(i) is not 0, the i-th column of is permuted to the front of A, otherwise column i is a free column. On exit, if JPVT(i) = k, then the i-th column of A* was the k-th column of .

PARAM_DESCRIPTION.SP: : the effective rank of , i.e., the order of the submatrix R1. This is the same as the order of the submatrix T in the complete orthogonal factorization of .
: real vector with 3 components; The estimates of some of the singular values of the triangular factor .
PARAM_DESCRIPTION.P: SVAL(1) is the largest singular value of R(1:RANK,1:RANK);
SVAL(2) is the smallest singular value of R(1:RANK,1:RANK);
SVAL(3) is the smallest singular value of R(1:RANK+1,1:RANK+1), if RAN < MIN(M,N), or of R(1:RANK,1:RANK), otherwise.

DESCRIPTION.P: To compute (optionally) a rank-revealing QR factorization of a real general M-by-N real or complex matrix , which may be rank-deficient, and estimate its effective rank using incremental condition estimation.
The routine uses a QR factorization with column pivoting:
DESCRIPTION.VERBATIM: A * P = Q * R, where R = [ R11 R12 ], [ 0 R22 ]
DESCRIPTION.P: with R1 defined as the largest leading submatrix whose estimated condition number is less than 1/RCON. The order of R1, RAN, is the effective rank of .

If the triangular factorization is a rank-revealing one (which will be the case if the leading columns were well- conditioned), then SVAL(1) will also be an estimate for the largest singular value of , and SVAL(2) and SVAL(3) will be estimates for the RAN-th and (RANK+1)-st singular values of , respectively.

By examining these values, one can confirm that the rank is well defined with respect to the chosen value of RCON. The ratio SVAL(1)/SVAL(2) is an estimate of the condition number of R(1:RANK,1:RANK).
